text: And Abram and Nahor took them wives: the name of Abram's wife was Sarai; and the name of Nahor's wife, Milcah, the daughter of Haran, the father of Milcah, and the father of Iscah.
text_kjv: And Abram and Nahor took them wives: the name of Abram's wife was Sarai; and the name of Nahor's wife, Milcah, the daughter of Haran, the father of Milcah, and the father of Iscah.
text_niv: Abram and Nahor both married. The name of Abram’s wife was Sarai, and the name of Nahor’s wife was Milcah; she was the daughter of Haran, the father of both Milcah and Iscah.
text_esv: And Abram and Nahor took wives. The name of Abram's wife was Sarai, and the name of Nahor's wife, Milcah, the daughter of Haran the father of Milcah and Iscah.
text_nlt: Meanwhile, Abram and Nahor both married. The name of Abram’s wife was Sarai, and the name of Nahor’s wife was Milcah. (Milcah and her sister Iscah were daughters of Nahor’s brother Haran.)
text_msg: Abram and Nahor each got married. Abram's wife was Sarai; Nahor's wife was Milcah, the daughter of his brother Haran. Haran had two daughters, Milcah and Iscah.
text_nasb: Abram and Nahor took wives for themselves. The name of Abram's wife was Sarai; and the name of Nahor's wife was Milcah, the daughter of Haran, the father of Milcah and Iscah.
context: Genesis 11:29 provides a snapshot into the familial relationships within Terah's lineage, setting the stage for God's covenant with Abram. Marriage customs in the ancient Near East, particularly within Mesopotamia (Ur of the Chaldees), often prioritized strengthening family ties and consolidating property. Endogamy, marriage within the family, was common, serving these purposes. Identifying Sarai and Milcah by name highlights their significance. Milcah's lineage is carefully traced – she is the daughter of Haran and therefore Abram's niece, emphasizing the close-knit nature of their society. Haran's designation as the father of both Milcah and Iscah suggests that Iscah might have been a less significant figure, or perhaps another daughter whose lineage needed clarification for inheritance or marital reasons. The mention of these women is crucial. Sarai, though initially barren, is destined to play a vital role in God's promise to Abram, becoming the mother of a nation. Milcah's line also continues, as she is the mother of Bethuel, the father of Rebekah, who will later marry Isaac, ensuring the continuation of the chosen lineage. Understanding the historical context of family structures and marriage practices illuminates the importance of lineage in this patriarchal society and underscores the significance of the women named in this verse, even beyond their immediate familial roles.
meaning: Theologically, Genesis 11:29 reveals God's providential hand at work even before his explicit covenant with Abram. The careful detailing of the family relationships serves as a subtle foreshadowing of the importance of lineage and descendants in God's plan of salvation. Abram's marriage to Sarai, despite her barrenness (which is revealed later), sets the stage for the miraculous intervention of God. The very fact that these women are mentioned by name suggests God's intention to use them, despite their apparent limitations, to fulfill His purposes. Milcah's connection to Rebekah, Isaac's wife, demonstrates how God orchestrates events across generations to keep his promises. The inclusion of Iscah, though less prominent, reminds us that God's ways are not always immediately apparent. The verse emphasizes that God can use ordinary families and circumstances to accomplish extraordinary things. It also speaks to the reliability of God's promises. Though Sarai is barren, God will ultimately fulfill his promise to Abram to make his descendants as numerous as the stars. Thus, the verse can be seen as a precursor to the covenant, preparing the reader to understand the miraculous nature of God's work in Abram's life and the importance of lineage in God's unfolding plan of redemption.
application: Genesis 11:29, while seemingly a simple statement of familial relationships, offers several practical applications for modern Christians. Firstly, it underscores the importance of family. In a society that often devalues family ties, this verse reminds us that God uses families to fulfill his purposes. We should invest in our families, nurture relationships, and recognize that God can work through even imperfect family situations. Secondly, it highlights the often-overlooked role of women in God's plan. Sarai and Milcah are not simply mentioned in passing; their lineage and marital status are specifically noted. This encourages us to recognize and value the contributions of women in our churches, communities, and families. Often, women are the unsung heroes, quietly influencing generations for God's glory. Thirdly, the verse reminds us that God can work through ordinary people. Abram, Sarai, and their relatives were not exceptional in any obvious way, yet God chose them to be the progenitors of a nation. We should not disqualify ourselves from serving God because we feel inadequate or ordinary. God uses the weak and foolish things of the world to shame the wise and strong. Fourthly, it teaches us about God's sovereignty. God's plans unfold across generations, often in ways we cannot understand. We should trust in his providence and seek to be faithful in the roles he has given us, even when we cannot see the full picture. Finally, the verse serves as a reminder that God's promises are reliable. Sarai's barrenness did not prevent God from fulfilling his promise to Abram. We can trust that God will keep his promises to us, even when circumstances seem impossible. This necessitates patience, faith, and unwavering reliance on His character.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for the reminder that you work through families and ordinary people to accomplish your extraordinary purposes. Help me to value my family and invest in those relationships, recognizing that you can use them to bless others. Lord, open my eyes to see the contributions of women around me and to honor their roles in your kingdom. Give me the faith to believe that you can use me, despite my weaknesses and limitations. Help me to trust in your sovereignty and to be faithful in the roles you have given me, even when I cannot see the full picture. I cling to your promises, knowing that you are faithful to fulfill them, even when circumstances seem impossible. Give me patience and unwavering trust in your character. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: The mention of Sarai's name is important because she will play a crucial role in God's covenant with Abram. Despite her initial barrenness, she is destined to be the mother of a great nation, highlighting God's miraculous intervention and faithfulness.
faqs.question: Q1: Why is it important that Sarai's name is mentioned specifically?

faqs.answer: Milcah's lineage underscores the significance of family ties in the ancient Near East. The careful tracing of her ancestry emphasizes the importance of family connections for inheritance, social status, and perpetuation of the family line.
faqs.question: Q2: What does Milcah's lineage tell us about the importance of family?

faqs.answer: Sarai's initial barrenness highlights the theme of God's power working through human limitations. Her eventual conception of Isaac demonstrates God's miraculous intervention and his ability to fulfill his promises despite seemingly impossible circumstances.
faqs.question: Q3: What can we learn from the fact that Sarai was initially barren?

faqs.answer: This verse foreshadows God's plan of redemption by highlighting the importance of lineage and descendants in fulfilling his promises. The emphasis on familial connections lays the groundwork for understanding the significance of Jesus' lineage in the New Testament.
faqs.question: Q4: How does this verse foreshadow God's plan of redemption?

faqs.answer: Iscah's presence, even with limited information, reminds us that God's purposes are not always fully revealed to us. Even seemingly minor figures can contribute to the unfolding of God's plan, even if their specific role remains unclear.
faqs.question: Q5: What does Iscah's presence in the verse signify if little else is known about her?
